ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to view and process the horror genre

(I was highly engaged with this course btw) I learned, in very broad strokes, some techniques for creating horror narratives. I have some idea of a working definition of what "horror" means, creatively. That's kind of it really.
This course developed my appreciation of the horror genre and helped me to define what, exactly, we mean by "horror."

This course is an excellent survey of the horror genre, with a deliberately expansive definition as to what the term "horror" encapsulates. Beyond helping students to hone both their analytical reading/writing and their creative writing, the course poses a lot of philosophical questions: Why do we need horror? What constitutes horror, and how does horror work? What social problems is horror responding to?

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: super cool readings and screenings

Weaknesses: prof is infuriatingly ignorant

strengths: great class discussions 
weaknesses: curricular readings

Strengths: materials in the syllabus are all pretty great and introduced me to some cool new stuff. 

Weaknesses: 

(1) Professor Deming's technique for guiding class discussion did not leave room for the conversation to organically follow the insights of the students, and he would often derail a promising conversation topic with some other point he wanted us to reach, but in doing so, neutered the discussion. It led to conversations that went in circles and we spent several days mostly hearing from the professor and not each other. This also led to an unfortunate situation where only students who felt compelled to and able to connect with what the professor was saying exactly to speak up and many more students stayed quiet because they felt that their insights were not necessarily what he wanted to hear, which was made clear when he would utterly dismiss students who did try to engage with his new point. The professor should take a step back in the conversation and really only jump in if he wants to ask a follow-up question. 

(2) The syllabi content is highly variable on a week-to-week basis. One week you may only have to watch a single 2 hour-long movie. Then another week you are expected to read an entire novel (300+ pages) of emotionally exhausting and potentially triggering content. More thought should be put into the organization of the syllabus; if the material itself cannot be compromised, the professor should consider recommending excerpts of pieces for the students to read and engage with before the class (perhaps students could be told to read Parts II and III of a novel which is closer to a standard weekly number of pages for assigned readings). 

(3) The professor's random selection of students to present on syllabus material is really a bad idea and created stress. Students had to reach out to him individually if they really had to change their presentation schedule, but it was given to us in a very non-negotiable way. Majority opinions I heard were that some students had pieces they wish they could have presented on, or at the very least, could have presented during a different week when they had less work going on. This was also disruptive when 3 or 4 weeks into the semester, the professor changed the syllabus order and content, disrupting students' expectations of their presenting schedule and materials. The professor should just let students sign up for their own weeks and time slots.

 (4) Conversations about subjects such as racism and sexual assault are not given the gravitas that they deserve nor the intellectual challenge they deserve. I can't offer a concrete suggestion for this but for this class in the future to not draw such a harsh line between "horror" and "social allusion" and to consider more seriously the social impact these materials have on their audiences and society as a whole. It seemed like conversations on these topics---when led by the professor---MORE often than NOT, tried to un-politicize them/be apolitical , which seems terribly ignorant AND ill-informed for a class self-titled AMERICAN horror stories when many of these horror stories are formed by. and in result of, very uniquely American horrors of colonization.

Professor Deming is a really incredible instructor and offers really great feedback! One weakness was that the seminar size was a little bit large, and so it was easier for the quieter personalities to get lost beneath the more vocal contributors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. I was super excited to take this class, but I was met with resistance at every attempt to steer the conversations towards what more students were interested in (namely sociopolitical issues like race, class, gender, sexuality, etc) as the prof insisted on sticking to a rigid agenda that no one could engage with
to be honest, if you have room in your schedule, yeah. but dont expect it to be amazing
Yes, take it! Really interesting course. You will look forward to each class.

I would recommend it to students who enjoy horror movies. Though I (not a horror movie person) enjoyed the course, I believe I would have gotten much more out of it if I were more interested in horror cinema.
Yesits really interesting to focus on such a niche subject. You learn a lot and I loved being introduced to something I wasnt familiar with before
